claim.hypothesis: Women will express more concern about COVID-19 than men.
claim.hypothesis_location: the abstract, also mentioned in the Summary section, p. 10.
claim.statement: In detail, 62.1% agree (answering either with“strongly agree” or“agree” onthe5-pointLikert Scale) that they are worriedabout COVID-19 in general (women=68.2%, men=55.7%, p<.01).

data.wave_or_subset: There is no specific subset but the data were collected from the 19th to the 23rd of March 2020.
data.access_details: no explicit mention in the text but the panel provider was responsible for data collection, so the data was probably sent to the authors

method.description: The authors analysed a representative online survey of German adults to examine gender, age, and regional differences in concern, fear, and coping strategies related to COVID-19.
method.steps:
1. The data was collected by an external panel provider, then cleaned. 
2. All respondents who took less than seven minutes to complete the questionnaire were removed. 
3. Then descriptives were calculated and reported.
method.models: the text doesn’t explicitly mention the model, but probably it was chi-squared

results.summary: About 62% of the respondents reported being worried about COVID-19, with women expressing more concern (68.2%) than men (55.7%) (p < .01).

metadata.original_paper_title: COVID-19: Risk perception and Coping strategies. Results from a survey in Germany.
